content: <metadata xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:fn="http://www.w3.org/2005/xpath-functions" xmlns:xdt="http://www.w3.org/2005/xpath-datatypes"><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>Idaho Transportation Department (ITD)</origin><pubdate>20121004</pubdate><pubtime>Unknown</pubtime><title>Bridges on the IdahoStateHighway System</title><geoform>vector digital data</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>ITD HQ Boise, ID  USA</pubplace><publish>Idaho Transportation Department (ITD)</publish></pubinfo><onlink>online</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>This is the bridge feature-class with the most precise locations, and the largest number of bridges and culverts without regard for whether the bridge is listed in the NBI or is on the State Highway System.  All bridges are "pinch points" that have the potential to completely block the flow of traffic on a road.</abstract><purpose>Emergency response, general planning, analysis, and location of bridges in the State of Idaho.</purpose><langdata>En</langdata><supplinf>none</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>20121004</caldate><time>unknown</time></sngdate></timeinfo><current>ground condition</current></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>Continually</update></status><spdom><bounding><westbc>-117.258359</westbc><eastbc>-110.684243</eastbc><northbc>49.019617</northbc><southbc>42.004861</southbc></bounding></spdom><keywords><theme><themekt>transportation</themekt><themekey>bridge</themekey><themekey>bridge location</themekey><themekey>structure number (identifier)</themekey><themekey>key number (identification)</themekey><themekey>milepost</themekey><themekey>segment code</themekey><themekey>crossing railroads</themekey><themekey>crossing river</themekey><themekey>crossing highway</themekey><themekey>underpass</themekey><themekey>overpass</themekey><themekey>Idaho Highways</themekey></theme><place><placekt>GNIS</placekt><placekey>State of Idaho</placekey><placekey>Idaho</placekey></place></keywords><accconst>This feature class is unclassified.</accconst><useconst>The Idaho Transportation Department (ITD) provides this geographic data and any associated metadata \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdas is\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd without warranty of any kind, including but not limited to its completeness, fitness for a particular use, or accuracy of its content, positional or otherwise. State St.</address><city>Boise</city><state>Idaho</state><postal>83703</postal><country>United States</country></cntaddr><cntvoice>(208) 334-8224</cntvoice><hours>8 to 5 - Mon - Fri</hours><cntemail>Roger.Kassens@itd.idaho.gov</cntemail><cntfax>(208) 334-4432</cntfax></cntinfo></ptcontac><datacred>Idaho Transportation Department, Bridge Inspection Section, and the National Bridge Inventory, and the USDA FSA NAIP aerial photography program.</datacred><native>Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7600) ; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850</native><natvform>ESRI</natvform></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>Some information is sparse.</attraccr><qattracc><attraccv>1</attraccv><attracce>none</attracce></qattracc></attracc><logic>Except for one bridge which cannot be located, all bridges have been located on the 2009 NAIP county images using the FSA image service out of UTAH.  All bridge features are at a bridge location, however they might not be the correct location.</logic><complete>Bridges from ITD's Bridge Inspection Unit and from existing bridge records in ITD's GIS Section, and from the FHWA National Bridge Inventory have been included in this feature class.  Additional bridges have been added when they were very obviously bridges or culverts.  It is my opinion that many bridges are still missing from this map, however I have not researched this.</complete><lineage><procstep><procdesc>The bridge database contains attributes for determining location by 2 methods, linear referencing and lat lon coordinates. A shapefile using each location method was generated.  The shapefile generated by lat lon oordinates was chosen as the file to keep and update. The shapefile created using linear referencing as well as various other layers useful for location reference were overlayed. NAIP imagery was the primary layer used for locating bridges and aligning roads. Each bridge feature was viewed individually.They were then moved to the appropriate location as observed on the NAIP image. Where road geometry was missing in ITDs' road layer for the bridge locations, it was added.   Where existing road geometry did not align with the NAIP imagery it was realigned. When discovered, inaccuracies to the linear referencing model were corrected.</procdesc><procdate>20121004</procdate><srcprod>BRIDGES</srcprod><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>Roger Kassens</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Transportation Department</cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>GIS Analyst</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype><address>3311 W. State St.</address><city>Boise</city><state>Id</state><postal>83707</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntvoice>208-334-8224</cntvoice><cntfax>208-334-4423</cntfax><cntemail>Roger.Kassens@Itd.Idaho.Gov</cntemail><hours>8 -
